case_name: Appellant v. Dr. D. P. Meshrarn

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 562 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 562 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 7, 8, 1963 of Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Appeal No. 115 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 7, 8, 1963, of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Bench  at Nagpur in Appeal No. 115 of 1962.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 Dr. D. P. Meshram was candidate for election to Maharashtra Legislative Assembly from constituency No. 190 Nagpur III reserved for scheduled castes.

anchor.surface_text: whether respondent No. 1 Dr. D. P. Meshrarn was entitled to be a candidate for election to the Maharashtra Legislative Assembly from companystituency No. 190 of Nagpur III, a companystituency reserved for candidates from scheduled castes.

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 4 were candidates nominated for election from the constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondents 1 to 4 were candidates duly numberinated for election to the Assembly from the aforesaid companystituency.

facts.text: Poll taken on February 27, 1962; respondent No. 1 polled highest votes and declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: The poll was taken on February 27, 1962 and respondent No. 1 who had polled the highest number of votes was declared elected.

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition alleging respondent No. 1 embraced Buddhism on March 17, 1957, ceased to be Scheduled Caste member, and guilty of corrupt practices.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon preferred an election petition before the Election Commission, the main allegations in -which were  a  that respondent No. 1 having embraced Buddhism on March 17, 1957 had ceased to be a member of a Scheduled Caste

facts.text: Tribunal held corrupt practices not established but respondent No. 1 embraced Buddhism, ineligible, set aside election; did not declare appellant elected.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the Corrupt practices alleged against respondent No. 1 were number established. It, however, came to the companyclusion that respondent No. 1 had embraced Buddhism as alleged by the appellant and was, therefore, number eligible...

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 appealed to Bombay High Court; High Court reversed Tribunal on conversion, upheld election.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of the Tribunal respondent No. 1 preferred an appeal before the High Court of Bombay. The only question which was urged before the High Court was regarding the alleged companyversion of respondent No. 1 to Buddhism.

facts.text: Mass conversion to Buddhism by Scheduled Castes persons at Nagpur on October 14, 1956 presided by Dr. Ambedkar; about 5 lakhs attended.

anchor.surface_text: there is the fact, which is admitted by respondent No. 1 himself, that a mass companyversion of a very large number of persons belonging to the Scheduled Castes to Buddhism took place at Nagpur on October 14, 1956 at a meeting which was presided over by Dr. Ambedkar.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was member of Dr. Ambedkar's party at time of 1956 mass conversion, did not attend due to work at water works.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 has admitted that he was a member, ,of Dr. Ambedkars party at that time and though he companyld number attend the companyversion ceremony -he had number.-dissociated himself, from it. According to him the reason why he did number attend thee ceremony was that he was then, busy with,, making arrangements at the, water works.

facts.text: Witnesses PW9 Ramrattan Janorkar, PW2 Akant Mate, PW5 Devaji Bhagat, PW10 Wasudeo Dongre testified to respondent No. 1's conversion on March 17, 1957 at Lashkari Bagh presided by Ramrattan.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his companytention that respondent No. 1. was company- verted to Buddhism on March 17, 1957 the appellant had ,adduced evidence of P.W. 9 Ramrattan Janorkar, P.W. 2 Akant Mate, P.W. 5 Devaji Bhagat and P.W. 10 Wasudeo Dongre.

facts.text: Appellant, witnesses PW2,5,9,10 and respondent No. 1 members of Republican Party of India; rift after Ambedkar's death into Haridas Awade group (appellant, witnesses) and Khobragade group (respondent No.1).

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed before us that these witnesses as well as respondent No. 1 were members of the Republican Party of India founded by the late Dr. Ambedkar and that some time after his death there was rift in the party...

facts.text: Declaration Ex. 42 dated July 5, 1957 signed by respondent No. 1 and others stating they embraced Buddhism on March 17, 1957 and no longer Harijans.

anchor.surface_text: The declaration is Ex. 42 and is dated July 5, 1957. It is to the following effect To whomsoever it may companycern- We, the following signatories, do hereby affirm that we embraced Buddha religion on 17-3-1957 and numberlonger since remain Harijans.

facts.text: Declaration signed after Nagpur Corporation meeting on July 5, 1957 where point raised no Scheduled Caste elected, needed under Act.

anchor.surface_text: The reason why this declaration came into existence is, according to the appellant, the following Elections had taken place to the Nagpur Corporation and a meeting was held on July 5, 1957 for selection of six additional members.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 admits signing declaration but claims under political pressure or duped by Akant Mate.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No.1 admits that he did sign this declaration but in his written statement the reason given by him is that he did so under political pressure. In his evidence, however, he has given a different explanation.

facts.text: Wedding invitation for respondent No. 1's daughters Lalita and Pushpa Lata to Sirish and Yashwant Rao bears picture of Lord Buddha and obeisances to Buddha.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 does number deny that the wedding invitation placed on record by the appellant bears his name as one of the hosts. The invitation pertains to the wedding of his daughters Lalita and Pushpa Lata

facts.text: Weddings performed according to Buddhist ritual as insisted by bridegrooms' side; engagements not broken.

anchor.surface_text: According to respondent No. 1 he did number know till after the Sakshyagandh  engagement  was over that either of the bride- grooms was a Buddhist. He says that a week before the marriages someone from the side of the bridegrooms met him

facts.text: Shiva temple near appellant's house in Gautamnagar converted to Buddha temple on June 6, 1959; respondent No. 1 presided, installed Buddha idol over Shiva Linga.

anchor.surface_text: According to them respondent No. 1 companyverted the Shiva Temple in Gautamnagar into Buddha temple on June 6, 1959 and installed Lord Buddhas image at a function over which he presided

facts.text: Witnesses PW11 Budhaji Godbole, PW14 Kisan Shende, appellant testified to Shiva temple conversion.

anchor.surface_text: there is the evidence of Budhaji Godbole, P.W. 11, and Kisan Shende, P.W. 14, in addition to that of the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 admitted most facts of temple conversion but claimed no Shiva temple constructed earlier on exchanged plot.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 had admitted most of the facts, as pointed out by the High Court itself. The variation between the companytentions of the parties is this. According to respondent No. 1 there was a Shiva Temple on a plot of land in Gaddigudam

facts.text: Supreme Court holds respondent No. 1 ceased to be Hindu, ineligible for reserved seat; allows appeal, restores Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons we are satisfied that respondent No. 1 had ceased to be a Hindu at the date of his numberination and that companysequently he was ineligible to be a candidate for election from a companystituency reserved for members of Scheduled Castes.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 7, 8, 1963, of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Bench  at Nagpur in Appeal No. 115 of 1962.
Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 and was thus disentitled from being a candidate for the particular seat and b that respondent No. 1 was guilty of several corrupt practices.

concepts.unlisted_description: Defines membership of Scheduled Caste requiring profession of Hindu or Sikh religion

anchor.surface_text: What cl. (3) of the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 contemplates is that for a person to be treated as one belonging to a Scheduled Caste within the meaning of that Order he must be one who professes either Hindu or Sikh religion.

concepts.interpretation: Requires professing Hindu or Sikh religion to be treated as Scheduled Caste member

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: yvert number- Buddhists to Buddhism. There is abundant evidence on record that at the companyversion ceremony held on October 14, 1956 Dr. Ambedkar ha

concepts.unlisted_description: No person professing religion other than Hindu or Sikh deemed Scheduled Caste member

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 3 of the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order reads thus .lm15 Notwithstanding anything contained in paragraph 2, no person who professes a religion different from the Hindu or the Sikh religion shall be deemed to be a member of a Scheduled Caste.

concepts.interpretation: Hindu used in narrow sense excluding Buddhists; specific mention of Sikhs implies exclusion of others like Buddhists

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: deemed to have embraced Buddhism from that date. It is, therefore, futile to say that others who went through the same procedure had number become Bu

concepts.unlisted_description: No person professing religion different from Hindu or Sikh deemed Scheduled Caste

anchor.surface_text: Explanation II to cl. (2) of Art. 25 of the Constitution. Clause (1) of Art. 25 recognises, amongst other things, freedom to practise and propagate religion.

concepts.interpretation: Expands 'Hindu' to include Sikhs, Jains, Buddhists only for purposes of Art. 25(2)(b) social reform and temple entry, not for Scheduled Castes Order

holdings.text: Respondent No. 1 had ceased to be a Hindu at the date of his nomination and consequently was ineligible to be a candidate for election from a constituency reserved for members of Scheduled Castes.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons we are satisfied that respondent No. 1 had ceased to be a Hindu at the date of his numberination and that companysequently he was ineligible to be a candidate for election from a companystituency reserved for members of Scheduled Castes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overwhelming evidence of public conversion (witness testimony, declaration Ex.42, wedding invitation with Buddha image, Shiva temple conversion to Buddha temple) shows respondent professed Buddhism; para 3 of SC Order excludes non-Hindu/Sikh from SC membership.

holdings.text: To 'profess' a religion under para 3 of Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 means to make an open public declaration or avowal of belief such that it is known to those interested; mere private belief insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: What cl. (3) of the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 contemplates is that for a person to be treated as one belonging to a Scheduled Caste within the meaning of that Order he must be one who professes either Hindu or Sikh religion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts High Court's view following Karwade v. Shambhakar; dictionary definitions (avow publicly, open declaration); applies to facts where public ceremony, signed declaration, and conduct evidence open profession of Buddhism.

holdings.text: Word 'Hindu' in para 3 of Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 used in narrow sense excluding Buddhists; Explanation II to Art. 25(2)(b) expands 'Hindu' only for that clause's social reform/temple entry purposes, not SC Order.

anchor.surface_text: Finally it is argued that the word Hindu is companyprehensive enough to include a Buddhist and in this companynection our attention is invited to Explanation 11 to cl.  2  of Art. 25 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific mention of 'Sikh' alongside 'Hindu' implies exclusion of others like Buddhists; Art.25 Expl.II expressly limited to sub-cl.(b) cl.2; no need for Sikh mention if wide definition intended.

holdings.text: Tribunal correctly set aside election of respondent No. 1; High Court judgment reversed and Tribunal order restored.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the Tribunal was right in setting aside his election. Accordingly we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore that of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reversal of High Court on facts (evidence credibility, misreading) and law (conversion effect); restores Tribunal's application of SC Order para 3.

holdings.text: Absence from register of converts does not negative conversion; no obligation to sign register.

anchor.surface_text: It is contened on behalf of respondent No. 1 that there is a register of persons who had been converted to Buddhism and that the first respondents name does not appear there.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Register not regularly maintained; signatures not mandatory by date; at best corroborative, not conclusive.

holdings.text: No requirement that only a Bhikku can convert non-Buddhists to Buddhism; recitation of three refuges and five precepts sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: Then it is said that only Bhikku is entitled to convert non- Buddhists to Buddhism. There is abundant evidence on record that at the conversion ceremony held on October 14, 1956 Dr. Ambedkar had told the new Buddhists...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ambedkar authorized others; same procedure as mass conversion by Ambedkar (no Bhikku needed); Buddhism protests orthodoxy/priest power; no authority cited requiring Bhikku.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, following its earlier decision in Karwade v. Shambhakar 1 has said that the meaning of the phrase professes a religion in the aforementioned provision is to enter publicly into a religious state and that for this purpose a mere declaration by person that he has ceased to belong to a particular religion and embraced another religion would number be sufficient. The meanings of the word profess have been given thus in Websters New Word Dictionary to avow publicly to make an open declaration of to declare ones belief in as, to profess I.L.R. 1959 Bom 229.

precedents.cited_proposition: the meaning of the phrase 'professes a religion' is to enter publicly into a religious state and that for this purpose a mere declaration by person that he has ceased to belong to a particular religion and embraced another religion would not be sufficient

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore that of the Tribunal. Costs throughout will be borne by respondent No.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside and Tribunal's judgment restored, thereby setting aside the election of respondent No. 1
directions: set aside the judgment of the High Court
